Title: Direct and indirect pathways from the amygdala to the frontal lobe in rhesus monkeys.
Abstract: To elucidate the anatomical relationships between the frontal association cortex and the limbic system in primates, projections from the amygdala to frontal cortex were studied in the rhesus monkey using retrograde and anterograde tracing methods. Following injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) into the orbital prefrontal cortex, the gyrus rectus, the superior frontal gyrus, and the anterior cingulate gyrus of the frontal lobe, labeled neurons were found in the basolateral, basomedial, or basal accessory nuclei of the amygdala. None of these nuclei contained labeled neurons following HRP injections into the principal sulcus or the lateral inferior convexity of the frontal lobe. This selective distribution of amygdala connections was confirmed by injection tritiated amino acids into the amygdala. Silver grains were present only over the orbital cortex and gyrus rectus on the ventral surface of the frontal lobe and over the superior prefrontal gyrus and anterior cingulate gyrus on the medial wall of the hemisphere, while the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex was free of radioactivity. The isotope injection of the amygdala also revealed a projection to the magnocellular moiety of the mediodorsal nucleus (MDmc) which is known to innervate the same ventromedial regions of the frontal lobe that receive direct connections from the amygdala. Although MDmc and amygdala project to the same cortical regions, their terminal fields are different. The direct amygdala input terminates in layer 1 in orbital cortex and gyrus rectus and layer 2 in the dorsomedial cortex and cingulate gyrus, while the thalamic input is primarily to layer 3 and, in some areas, also the superficial half of layer 1. These findings indicate that the frontal lobe of rhesus monkeys can be subdivided into two separable cortical regions: 1) A ventromedial region including the anterior cingulate gyrus which receives both direct (amygdalo-cortical) and indirect (amygdalo-thalamo- cortical) input from the amygdala; and 2) a dorsolateral frontal region which is essentially devoid of either direct or indirect amygdalofugal axons. On the basis of its selective relationship with the amygdala, the ventromedial region may be considered the "limbic" portion of the frontal association cortex.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "In order to describe and discuss the present findings, it is essential to define the cytoarchitectonic boundaries of the amygdaloid complex used in the present study. In the rhesus monkey, as in most other mammalian species, the amygdaloid complex is situated in an anteromedial position in the temporal lobe, separated from medial-temporal cortical fields by fibers from the external capsule. For purposes of presentation, we adopted the nomenclature for the amygdaloid complex used by Crosby and Humphrey ('41) and Jimenez- Castellanos ('49). ..."   (p. 125)

@Injections.Citation: "In order to expose the full extent of amygdalo-cortical projections more directly, the amygdala was injected with tritiated amino acids. Examination of the injection site indicated that radioactivity was spread over all nuclear components of t eamygdala. The dense concentration of silver grains in the emulsion overlying the injected area was visible without the aid of a microscope and was traced directly from sections that were phhotographically enlarged (Fig. 3). Other adjacent structures including anterior portions of the hippocampus and the overlying mediotemporal and entorhinal cortex alsocontained some label by diffusion of the radioactive isotope. However, none of these mesotemporal structures have significant projections to prefrontal cortex in monkey (Van Hoesen and Pandya, '75; Potter and Nauta, '79), a conclusion which is borne out as well by our own retrograde transport data in which few if any labeled cells were found in the mesotemporal cortex in the vicinityof the amygdala. It is important to note that anterolateral temporal cortices areas on the inferior and superior temporal gyri which do project to the prefrontal cortex via the uncinate fasciculus (Nauta, '71; Pandya and Kuypers, '69) were not labeled (See A in Fig. 3). " (125-126)
@Injections.Comments: It is said that some allocortical structures are affected by the injection, but the authors say that they have no pregnant consequences.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: The text on pages 126-130 does not explicitly say which areas of the prefrontal cortex are labeled or not. For comparison on page 133 (discussion) you can find more detailed information about (un-) labeled prefrontal areas.

@Injections.Citation: "Radioactive amino acids were next injected into the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus in order to verify the amygdala's indirect loop to the cortex and to demonstrate the laminar pattern of termination of MD in the prefrontal cortex. The injection site was centered in the posterior portions of MD and involved both the magnocellular and parvocellular components of the nucleus. " (p. 130)

" Seven rhesus monkeys of both sexes ranging in weight from        2-4kg received intracerebral injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) into one of six prefrontal association cortical fields: 1) the superior prefrontal gyrus on the dorsomedial wall of the hemisphere; 2) the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus and adjacent dorsal convexity; 3) the ventral bank of the principal sulcus; 4) the lateral inferior convexity; 5) the medial orbital and rectus gyri; and 6) the frontal pole (Fig. 1). Because of its anatomical relationship to prefrontal cortex , the anterior cingulate gyrus was also injected. The sites together comprise all major cytoarchitectonic territories of the prefrontal association and adjacent limbic cortex defined in Walker ('40)."  (p. 122)
"Localization of HRP injection sites
The full extent of each injection site is shown in Figure 1. The dorsomedial injection was concentrated to the superior prefrontal gyrus on the dorsomedial aspect of the hemisphere bordering the dorsal margin of the callosal marginal sulcus. Rostrally it encompassed the medial part of Walker 's ('40) area 9 which begins at the anterior limit of the callosal  marginal sulcus. Caudally the injection extended into Walker 's area 8B and the anterior portion of area 6 behind the genu of the corpus callosum. The injection in the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus labeled the rim and depth of the dorsal bank of the principal sulcus along its rostral-caudal extent (Walker 'sarea 46). A similar injection in the ventral bank of the principal sulcus, also area 46, likewise extended along the entire rostral-caudal limits of the sulcus. The injection of the inferior convexity of the lobe extended from the inferior frontal gyrus on the lateral convexity to the lateral orbital sulcus on the ventral surface of the lobe. The labeled area, which is co-extensive with Walker 's area 12, ws comparatively large, spreading caudally almost to the level of the insula. The smallest injection was that made in the posterior medial orbital cortex (Walker 's area 13).The medial boundary of this injection was the gyrus rectus; laterally the injection bordered the lateral orbital sulcus. The frontal pole injection covered Walker 's area 10 but extended caudally into the gyrus rectus (area 14) on the ventral and medial surfaces of the hemisphere. The injection of the cingulate gyrus labeled approximately the anterior fifth of this cortex beginning rostral to the genu of the corpus callosum. This region corresponds to Walker 's area 24.
The area of labeling in all seven injections was mainly confined to the cortex , but there was some involvement of white matter in the larger injection fields. In no case was there any labeling of subcortical structure." (pp. 123, 125)
@Injections.Comments: This case has been called the "frontal pole injection" by the authors.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " No HRP-positive cells were found following HRP injections into dorsal principal sulcus, ventral principal sulcus, or inferior convexity sites." (p. 124, description of figure 2)

The injection of the inferior convexity of the lobe extended from the inferior frontal gyrus on the lateral convexity to the lateral orbital sulcus on the ventral surface of the lobe. The labeled area, which is co-extensive with Walker 's area 12, ws comparatively large, spreading caudally almost to the level of the insula. The smallest injection was that made in the posterior medial orbital cortex (Walker 's area 13).The medial boundary of this injection was the gyrus rectus; laterally the injection bordered the lateral orbital sulcus. The frontal pole injection covered Walker 's area 10 but extended caudally into the gyrus rectus (area 14) on the ventral and medial surfaces of the hemisphere. The injection of the cingulate gyrus labeled approximately the anterior fifth of this cortex beginning rostral to the genu of the corpus callosum. This region corresponds to Walker 's area 24.
The area of labeling in all seven injections was mainly confined to the cortex , but there was some involvement of white matter in the larger injection fields. In no case was there any labeling of subcortical structure." (pp. 123, 125)
@Injections.Comments: This case has been called the "cingulate gyrus injection" by the authors.

publication.title: Direct and indirect pathways from the amygdala to the frontal lobe in rhesus monkeys.
publication.abstract: To elucidate the anatomical relationships between the frontal association cortex and the limbic system in primates, projections from the amygdala to frontal cortex were studied in the rhesus monkey using retrograde and anterograde tracing methods. Following injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) into the orbital prefrontal cortex, the gyrus rectus, the superior frontal gyrus, and the anterior cingulate gyrus of the frontal lobe, labeled neurons were found in the basolateral, basomedial, or basal accessory nuclei of the amygdala. None of these nuclei contained labeled neurons following HRP injections into the principal sulcus or the lateral inferior convexity of the frontal lobe. This selective distribution of amygdala connections was confirmed by injection tritiated amino acids into the amygdala. Silver grains were present only over the orbital cortex and gyrus rectus on the ventral surface of the frontal lobe and over the superior prefrontal gyrus and anterior cingulate gyrus on the medial wall of the hemisphere, while the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex was free of radioactivity. The isotope injection of the amygdala also revealed a projection to the magnocellular moiety of the mediodorsal nucleus (MDmc) which is known to innervate the same ventromedial regions of the frontal lobe that receive direct connections from the amygdala. Although MDmc and amygdala project to the same cortical regions, their terminal fields are different. The direct amygdala input terminates in layer 1 in orbital cortex and gyrus rectus and layer 2 in the dorsomedial cortex and cingulate gyrus, while the thalamic input is primarily to layer 3 and, in some areas, also the superficial half of layer 1. These findings indicate that the frontal lobe of rhesus monkeys can be subdivided into two separable cortical regions: 1) A ventromedial region including the anterior cingulate gyrus which receives both direct (amygdalo-cortical) and indirect (amygdalo-thalamo- cortical) input from the amygdala; and 2) a dorsolateral frontal region which is essentially devoid of either direct or indirect amygdalofugal axons. On the basis of its selective relationship with the amygdala, the ventromedial region may be considered the "limbic" portion of the frontal association cortex.
